text: Eʋegbe me, serial verb construction wɔ ne sia sia a verb evewo alo geɖe ɖe woɖe sentence ɖeka me, eye mekpɔ ame si wɔ kpɔkpɔɖeŋu le verbawo dome o.
translation: In Ewe, a serial verb construction consists of two or more verbs occurring in a single clause without a conjunction between them.

text: Wɔ Eʋegbe me no, serial verbawo wɔ sentence ɖeka me le tense kple aspect si woɖe ɖeka si wotsɔ ɖe verbawo katã dzi.
translation: In Ewe, all verbs in a serial verb construction share the same tense and aspect marking.

text: Serial verb construction le Eʋegbe me kɔ asɛmɖeɖe si verbawo kɔɖeɖe le sentence ɖeka me eye wotsɔ wo kɔ ɖe asɛm ɖeka ƒe nuwɔwɔ.
translation: In Ewe, serial verb constructions are used to express actions in which verbs occur together in one sentence to describe one situation.

text: Eʋegbe me, aspect mekpɔ nu ɖeka kple tense o; aspect tsɔ gomeɖeɖeɖe si asɛm le wɔwɔwɔ me alo nu si wowɔ vɔ.
translation: In Ewe, aspect is distinct from tense and indicates whether an action is in progress or has been completed.

text: Le sukuwɔnu si wotsɔ fia le Eʋegbe kɔkɔeawo me la, aspect marker le verb la ŋgɔ alo megbe, sɛ́nea wotsɔ kɔ asɛm la ƒe gomeɖeɖeɖe.
translation: In the lesson examples, aspect markers occur before or after the verb as shown.

text: Dekɔnudziɖuɖu enye wɔna alo nɔnɔme si me wokplɔa du alo nuto aɖe le.
translation: Traditional governance is the process or manner in which a town or a specific area is governed.

source.document: Ghanaian-Languages_CULTURAL PRACTICES AND GOVERNANCE ewe Version.pdf

text: Vifofoe nye tato le fome abɔkpui si me woɖua tɔnu le la. Le fome siwo me woɖua nɔnu le la, nyɔnu (vidada) tea ŋu nyea tato.
translation: The father is the head of the nuclear family in patrilineal systems. In matrilineal systems, a woman (mother) can be the head.

source.document: Ghanaian-Languages_CULTURAL PRACTICES AND GOVERNANCE ewe Version.pdf

text: Hlɔtatɔwoe nye tato na hlɔwo. Hlɔmetɔwoe tiaa hlɔtatɔ la.
translation: Clan heads are the heads of clans. The clan members elect the clan head.

source.document: Ghanaian-Languages_CULTURAL PRACTICES AND GOVERNANCE ewe Version.pdf

text: Woyɔa Biblia le Eʋegbe me be 'Agbenya La'.
translation: The Bible is called 'Agbenya La' (The Word of Life) in Ewe.

text: Le Eʋegbe Biblia me la, woyɔa Dɔwɔwɔwo be 'Acts' le Eŋlisigbe me, eye woyɔa Ʋɔnudrɔ̃lawo be 'Judges'.
translation: In the Ewe Bible, 'Dɔwɔwɔwo' is Acts, and 'Ʋɔnudrɔ̃lawo' is Judges.

text: Trɔ̃ nye gbɔgbɔ si amewo subɔna. Eʋeawo xɔe se be trɔ̃wo kpɔ ŋusẽ ɖe yewoƒe agbenɔnɔ kple nuwɔnawo dzi.
translation: A deity is a god or goddess that people worship. Ewes believe that deities have power over their lives and actions.

text: Subɔsubɔŋkɔ nye ŋkɔ si wotsɔ na amewo ku ɖe woƒe dzixɔse kple nu siwo wosubɔna la ŋu.
translation: A deity name is a name given to people based on their worship and the deity they follow.

text: Subɔsubɔŋkɔwo ɖea dzilawo ƒe dzixɔse fiana eye wonaa nutsotso tso ale si trɔ̃ la na nyɔnua fɔ fu la ŋu.
translation: Deity names reflect the family's faith and connection to the deity; the traits of the deity are expected to manifest in the person bearing that name.

text: Tsitsimekɔnu nye kɔnu si wowɔna na ame le tsitsime. Tsitsimekɔnu nye kɔnu si wowɔna na ŋutsuvi alo nyɔnuvi tsɔna ɖenɛ fiana be etsi eye wòate ŋu awɔ nu abe ame tsitsi ene.
translation: Puberty rites are ceremonies performed for adolescents to mark their transition to adulthood and maturity.

text: Gbɔtowɔwɔ nye tsitsimekɔnu si wowɔna na nyɔnuviwo. Do ŋgɔ na kɔnua wɔwɔ: wodea dzesi tɔtrɔ siwo va nyɔnuvi la me; wonaa nyanya nyɔnu tsitsi siwo nye kɔnua wɔlawo la.
translation: Gbɔtowɔwɔ are the puberty rites for girls. Before the main ceremony: preparations are made to the girl; teachings are given by elder women.

text: Dekɔnudziɖuɖu enye dziɖuɖu si me ame geɖewo ƒe wɔƒe le eye amewo wɔna ɖe nunɔlawo ƒe gbeɖeɖewo dzi le dekɔnu ƒe ɖoɖowo nu.
translation: Traditional governance is a system in which many people have roles, and decisions are made collaboratively following customary law.

text: Vifofoe nye tatɔ le ƒome abɔkpui si lɔ fofo la ŋutɔ, srɔ̃a kple viawo ɖe eme la. Vifofowo kpɔa ame siwo le ƒomea me la ƒe hiãhiãwo gbɔ.
translation: The father is the head of the nuclear family, which consists of himself, his wife, and children. Fathers are responsible for the welfare of family members.

text: Hlɔ̃tatɔ nye tatɔ na hlɔ̃ alo amewo dome ʋukadodo aɖe le la. Hlɔ̃metɔwoe tiaa hlɔ̃tatɔ la.
translation: A clan head is the leader of a clan (a group of people related by kinship). Clan members elect the clan head.

text: Fiagã nye fia alo ame si ɖu du vovovo siwo ƒo ƒu wɔ nuto ɖeka dzi la. Enye tatɔ na du vovovowo ƒe fiawo.
translation: A paramount chief is a leader who governs multiple towns that form one kingdom. He is the highest authority over all the towns' chiefs.

text: Dufia/Tofia le fiagã la te. Dufiawo le fiagãwo te eye tofiawo le dufiawo te. Dufiawo kple tofiawo ɖua fia ɖe duwo kple kɔƒewo dzi.
translation: Sub-chiefs are subordinate to the paramount chief. Division chiefs oversee multiple towns; town chiefs oversee individual towns.

text: Fiatɔwo nye ame siwo kpɔa fiaɖoɖo dzi eye wowɔa wɔƒe geɖewo le fiaɖoɖo me. Fiatɔwo meɖua fia o. Wodoa go hedea ŋugble tso ame si woaɖo fiae la ŋu.
translation: Kingmakers are people who play roles in the selection of chiefs. They do not become chiefs themselves but have influence over succession.

text: Tsiƒoɖi nye gbedodoɖa na Mawugã to tɔgbeawo dzi. Enye wɔna si me wozãa dzatsi kple aha sesẽ le la.
translation: Libation is a form of prayer or invocation to God and ancestors. It involves pouring water or alcohol on the ground.

text: Tsiƒoɖi ƒe tutuɖo to nuʋuʋu (yɔyɔ tɔgbeawo), tsia ƒoƒo ɖi (gaŋɔ), kple taƒoƒo (akpe kple aha) dzi.
translation: Libation has three parts: invocation (calling on deities/ancestors), message (stating the purpose), and conclusion (offering thanks and blessings).

text: Avihɛ nye ha si yɔ fũu kple konyifafa kple vevesese. Wogadzia avihɛwo tsɔna kafua ameyinugbewo alo dea bubu wo ŋu.
translation: A dirge is a mournful song or hymn sung to mourn the dead and express grief during funeral rites.

text: Ŋutinya nye nyadu ŋlɔɖiwo dometɔ ɖeka. Enye nyadu si zɔna ɖe nuƒoƒo kple gbezazã ƒe ɖoɖowo nu.
translation: Prose is a form of written literature. It is a narrative written in ordinary language following the flow of speech.

text: Nu siwo ŋutinya lɔ ɖe eme nye: nuwɔlawo (ame alo lã), nyati (gbedeasi), ŋutinya ƒe zɔzɔme (ale si nuwɔnawo zɔ), teƒe kple ɣeyiɣi.
translation: Elements of prose include: characters (people or animals), theme (main idea/message), plot (sequence of events), and setting (place and time).
